page.title: List of Nobel laureates affiliated with King's College London

revision.text:
{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} [[File:Strand102.jpg|thumb|220px|Twelve Nobel laureates have been affiliated with [[King's College London]]. The building pictured is the Embankment terrace entrance to the Strand Campus overlooking the [[River Thames]].]] The [[Nobel Prize]]s are awarded annually by the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]], the [[Karolinska Institute]], and the [[Norwegian Nobel Committee]] to individuals who make outstanding contributions in the fields of [[Nobel Prize in Chemistry|chemistry]], [[Nobel Prize in Physics|physics]], [[Nobel Prize in Literature|literature]], [[Nobel Peace Prize|peace]], and [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine|physiology or medicine]].{{cite web | title = Alfred Nobel – The Man Behind the Nobel Prize | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/alfred_nobel/|accessdate=2009-03-14}} They were established by the 1895 will of [[Alfred Nobel]], which dictates that the awards should be administered by the [[Nobel Foundation]]. Another prize, the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]], was established in 1968 by the [[Sveriges Riksbank]], the [[central bank]] of [[Sweden]], for contributors to the field of economics.{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/|title=The Nobel Prize|publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]]|accessdate=2009-03-14}} Each prize is awarded by a separate committee: the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences awards the Prizes in Physics, Chemistry, and Economics, the Karolinska Institute awards the Prize in Physiology or Medicine, and the Norwegian Nobel Committee awards the Prize in Peace.{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Awarders |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |accessdate=2009-03-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015013145/http://nobelprize.org/prize_awarders/ |archivedate=2008-10-15 }} Each recipient receives a medal, a diploma and a cash prize that has varied throughout the years. In 1901, the winners of the first Nobel Prizes were given 150,782 [[Swedish krona|SEK]], which is equal to 7,731,004 SEK in December 2007. In 2008, the winners were awarded a prize amount of 10,000,000 SEK.{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Amounts |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html |accessdate=2009-03-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205035938/http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/amounts.html |archivedate=February 5, 2009 }} The awards are presented in [[Stockholm]] in an annual ceremony on December 10, the [[anniversary]] of Nobel's death.{{cite web|title=The Nobel Prize Award Ceremonies |publisher=[[Nobel Foundation]] |url=http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ |accessdate=2009-03-14 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228154556/http://nobelprize.org/award_ceremonies/ |archivedate=February 28, 2009 }} As of 2013, there have been 12 Nobel laureates affiliated with [[King's College London]]. King's College considers laureates who attended the university as undergraduate students, graduate students or were members of the faculty as affiliated laureates.{{cite web|url=https://www.kcl.ac.uk/about/history/people/nobel.html|title=King's Nobel laureates|publisher=[[King's College London]]|accessdate=2009-03-14}} [[Charles Glover Barkla]], who served as the Professor of Physics at King's College from 1909 to 1913, was the first King's College-affiliated laureate, winning the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1917.{{cite web | title = The Nobel Prize in Physics 1917 | publisher = [[Nobel Foundation]] | url = http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1917/index.html|accessdate=2009-03-14}} Nine of the Twelve King's College laureates were recipients of the Nobel Prize in Physics or the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine; the remaining laureates being awarded for Chemistry, Peace and Literature. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Laureates== {|class="wikitable sortable" width="98%" style="background:#ffffff;" |- !
